awd_titl_txt: Enhancing High-resolution Terrain Data Model for Improving the Delineation of Multi-scale Hydrological Connectivity
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is to create a new geospatial and hydrological modeling approach that improves the identification of rivers and streams using high-resolution digital elevation models (HRDEMs). Accurate identification of these river and stream networks is necessary for monitoring environmental process such as the transport of nutrients and aquatic species. The results will create an intelligent hydrological model by combining methods in geographic information sciences, artificial intelligence and cyberinfrastructure that will enable multi-scale analysis of river and stream networks. The model, algorithms, and datasets generated from this project will be freely available to the public and benefit a broad scope of natural resources management activities, such as watershed monitoring, wetland conservation, and aquatic species protection. The results of this work will be incorporated into educational curriculums and disseminated to the broader educational community.

There is a critical need for datasets and modeling approaches that can be used to generate hydrologically corrected HRDEMs and delineate hydrologic features like wetlands, road culverts and bridges at a fine scale. To improve the modeling accuracy, this project will develop a geospatial artificial intelligence-hydrological modeling framework that is compatible with HRDEMs. A deep learning model and an image dataset of drainage crossing locations will be developed to identify the locations of hydraulic drainage structures as virtual flow barriers. The effects of hydraulic drainage structures, HRDEM resolutions, and flow direction algorithms on the delineated hydrologic features and their connectivity will be assessed via controlled experiments for an optimal combination. The model will be implemented on high-performance computing clusters to speed up the geocomputation. This project will substantially advance the state-of-the-art of terrain-based hydrologic modeling integrating methods in geographic information science, artificial intelligence, and cyberinfrastructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The characterization of hydrologic connectivity is critical for environmental management issues such as overland nutrient loss and fish passage over barriers. The multi-scale delineation of overland flow routing helps understand how hydrologic networks interconnect across agricultural landscapes. However, digital elevation models (DEMs) with high spatial details often exhibit challenges that widespread road bumps block or cause incorrect flow routing at drainage crossing locations. Therefore, a key focus of this project was to develop deep learning approaches to determine the locations of these drainage crossing locations, which is a significant improvement over traditional methods that rely on labor-intensive digitization and field surveys.

One of the key outcomes of this project was the development and application of basic and advanced convolutional neural network (CNN) models for recognizing images containing drainage crossings using high-resolution DEMs and aerial orthophotos. The study finds that CNN models, particularly those utilizing DEMs as the sole input feature, achieve the highest classification accuracy exceeding 93%. The best-fit models exhibit excellent transferability across four watersheds in California, Nebraska, North Dakota, and Illinois respectively. Building on the success of image classification, we developed deep learning models to accurately detect the locations of drainage crossings. Additionally, the research team assessed the effectiveness of processing high-resolution DEMs at these crossing sites to enhance flowline representation. The findings demonstrate that the incorporation of drainage crossings into DEMs significantly improves the precision of flowline delineation, resulting in more accurate representations of drainage features.

The models and datasets developed through this project have been extensively disseminated via peer-reviewed publications, presentations, and NSF-funded training workshops. To date, the project has resulted in ten peer-reviewed articles (including one pending minor revisions) and numerous presentations at national and regional conferences, such as the American Association of Geographers (AAG) annual meetings and the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meetings. In addition to contributing to the academic community, the project has provided significant training and educational opportunities for researchers at various career stages, including postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, undergraduate students, and even high school students. Notably, one Ph.D. student and one M.S. student, both supervised by the Principal Investigator, completed their dissertation and thesis directly based on this project. Furthermore, the project’s outcomes have supported advanced training in GPU cyberinfrastructure through a separate NSF-funded workshop grant, delivering professional development benefits to approximately 30 graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. Finally, the models and datasets developed from this project have been shared with key stakeholders, such as the U.S. Geological Survey, Illinois Departments of Transportation, and academic institutions.
